I’m currently working as a [software engineer](https://cj.rs/cv) at Cloudflare, where I get to work with exciting technologies like [eBPF](https://cj.rs/tags/ebpf/?ref=lobsters-profile). I enjoy writing and contributing to [open-source](https://cj.rs/open-source?ref=lobsters-profile) programs. I [blog](https://cj.rs/blog?ref=lobsters-profile) mainly about [performance](https://cj.rs/tags/performance/?ref=lobsters-profile) and [tools I use](https://cj.rs/blog/my-setup?ref=lobsters-profile). You can find me in various [parts](https://cj.rs/contact/?ref=lobsters-profile#find-me-on) of the internet.

This is an OpenPGP proof that connects my OpenPGP key to this Lobste.rs account. For details check out https://docs.keyoxide.org/advanced/openpgp-proofs/

title: Tools for tag-based file management?
description:
Tag-based file management seems like a great idea, and would address a lot of the shortcomings of hierarchical directory structures. However, the tools that I have found for tag-based file management on Linux — TMSU, Tagsistant, and TagSpaces — have some severe limitations.

Are there any good options that I have missed? What tool do you use, if any?

Thanks!
description_plain:
Tag-based file management seems like a great idea, and would address a lot of the shortcomings of hierarchical directory structures. However, the tools that I have found for tag-based file management on Linux — TMSU, Tagsistant, and TagSpaces — have some severe limitations.

Are there any good options that I have missed? What tool do you use, if any?

Thanks!

submitter_user.about: An autodidact crafting code + content for the web. I write about amateur neuroscience on [The Autodidacts](http://autodidacts.io), and built [NeuroBB](http://neurobb.com), [Algebrarules.com](http://algebrarules.com), [Automathic.org](http://automathic.org), [EEGrunt](http://github.com/curiositry/EEGrunt), some blog themes, and more. Open-source enthusiast/evangelist. Find me [GitHub](http://github.com/curiositry) and [Twitter](http://twitter.com/curiositry).
